Dear Shawna Henry:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/26/24, staff was sleeping on shift. Two youth snuck out of
their rooms and went into the rooms of other youth and engaged
in sexual intercourse.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 5/22/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Complainant reported they
had no additional information regarding the 4/26/24 incident
because they received the information second and third hand.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at a neighbor’s home on
5/10/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported
he was at the facility for 3 weeks and left on 5/7/24. Youth A
reported he didn’t remember a staff with Staff 1’s name who
worked at night. Youth A reported he never saw any staff fall
asleep during their shifts. Youth A reported most staff completed
bed checks every 15 minutes at night, but one staff (couldn’t
remember who) completed checks at longer intervals (30-35
minutes) and quit last week (between 4/29/24-5/3/24). Youth A
reported there is a rule no youth are allowed in each other’s rooms
and no staff were flexible with the rule or allowed it to be broken.
Youth A reported he never had any other youth, including Youth
C, in his room. Youth A reported he doesn’t know why anyone
would say he and Youth C did anything sexual because it never
happened. Youth A reported he didn’t know if Youth B and Youth
D did anything sexual with each other or went in each other’s
rooms.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at school on 5/10/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported he was at
the facility from 4/25/24-5/9/24. Youth B reported staff completed
bed checks every 15-20 minutes at night, and he didn’t remember
any staff who completed checks in longer timeframes. Youth B
reported he didn’t remember a staff with Staff 1’s name because
2

he didn’t pay much attention to night staff. Youth B reported he
never saw any staff sleeping on shift. Youth B reported he didn’t
know there was a rule youth couldn’t be in each other’s rooms.
Youth B reported the first or second night he was at the facility
Youth D came into his room after bedtime and they had
consensual sexual contact. Youth B estimated Youth D was in his
room for about 2 hours. Youth B reported during the 2-hour
timeframe, a male staff (couldn’t remember who) only conducted
one bed check. During the bed check, the staff opened the
bedroom door, peeked inside, and left. Youth B reported he and
Youth D were sitting up on his bed leaning against the wall when
the staff opened his door, so the staff should have seen them, but
since they didn’t get in trouble, he assumed the staff didn’t.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at her residence on
5/10/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported
she was at the facility from 4/8/24-4/28/24. Youth C reported she
remembered Staff 1 and stated he worked 3rd shift. Youth C
reported she saw Staff 1 asleep at the table in the recreation room
on the night of 4/25/24-4/26/24 but didn’t know what time he fell
asleep or how long he was sleeping. Youth C reported she wasn’t
sure if Staff 1 missed any bed checks while he was sleeping or
any other time throughout the night. Youth C reported staff are
supposed to complete bed checks every 15 minutes and they
open the bedroom doors so they can see the youth. Youth C
reported when Staff 1 completed bed checks, it seemed it was
every 30 minutes instead of every 15 minutes. Youth C reported
the facility has a rule youth are not supposed to be in each other’s
rooms, but sometimes, Staff 1 was flexible with the rule if the
youth were the same gender. Youth C reported she never went in
Youth A’s bedroom, and they never did anything sexual with each
other. Youth C reported Youth D went to Youth B’s bedroom a
couple days before Youth C left the facility, but she didn’t know
how long Youth D was in Youth B’s bedroom or what happened
between them.
Youth D was interviewed via phone on 5/10/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth D reported she was
at the facility from 4/20/24-5/9/24. Youth D reported staff
completed bed checks every 15 minutes, but there was a male
staff (didn’t know his name) who didn’t ever do checks. Youth D
reported she never saw any staff sleeping on shift. Youth D
reported she didn’t remember a staff with Staff 1’s first name.
Youth D reported the night of 4/25/24-4/26/24, she made her bed
look like someone was sleeping in it by putting
pillows/blankets/etc. under the covers. Then she walked into the
3

hallway outside her room, snuck through the door leading to the
boy’s hallway, and went into Youth B’s room from approximately
1:30-3:00 AM. Youth D reported she hid under Youth B’s bed at
first, but then came out from under the bed and had sex with
Youth B in his bed. Youth D reported a male staff (didn’t know his
name) was sitting at the table in the recreation room when she
snuck out of her room. Youth D reported while she was in Youth
B’s room, Staff 1 did not complete any bed checks. Youth D
reported the same night, Youth C snuck into Youth A’s bedroom,
and they also did something sexual with each other.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/22/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported from 4/25/24-4/26/24, he
remembered there was a lot of movement from all the youth, so
around 12 AM on 4/26/24, he told them to go to bed. Staff 1
reported all four youth finally ended up going to bed, so he put his
air pods in his ears and was “just chillin’”. Staff 1 reported when he
completed bed checks throughout the night, everything seemed
fine. Staff 1 reported he thought he completed all checks as
required, but it’s possible he missed 2-3 bed checks throughout
the night. Staff 1 reported when he completed one bed check, he
saw a towel in the door in between the boy’s/girl’s hallway, so he
removed it. Staff 1 reported he completes bed checks by knocking
on the door, peeking in, and looking to see if he sees part of the
youth’s body. Staff 1 reported he didn’t see anything unusual in
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C or Youth D’s room when he completed
bed checks, and he was positive he saw each youth in their own
beds each time he completed a check. Staff 1 reported if he would
have seen any youth in another youth’s room, he would have told
them to leave. Staff 1 reported he doesn’t remember if he dozed
off or slept during the shift. Staff 1 expressed shocked when he
was told he only completed one bed check between 12:50 AM-
2:50 AM. Staff 1 took accountability for his actions, apologized,
and said he should have been more alert during the shift. Staff 1
reported he left his position at the facility because he was dozing
off on some of his shifts.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/22/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 1 reported she is
Staff 1’s direct supervisor. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 fell asleep
on 3rd shift when he first started working at the facility, and another
staff woke him up. Supervisor 1 reported it happened again in
January 2024. Supervisor 1 reported after the second incident,
they moved Staff 1 to 1st/2nd shift instead. However, on one 1st
shift, Staff 1 fell asleep 2-3 times during the same shift. The
director could hear him snoring, so she woke him up. On 2/27/24,
4

Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 met with Staff 1 and expressed
their concern about his ability to fulfill his role and expectations at
the facility. Supervisor 1 reported they gave Staff 1 a few days to
think about it and decide what he wanted to do. Supervisor 1
reported Staff 1 called and said he wanted to continue working at
the facility and wanted to continue working 3rd shift, so they
allowed him to. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 1 agreed if he was
having any problems staying awake, he would call her. Supervisor
1 reported at the time of Staff 1’s 90-day evaluation in April 2024,
she was going to terminate him based on continued concerns with
him dozing off on shift. However, Staff 1 provided his 2 weeks’
notice at the evaluation meeting and his last day was scheduled
for 5/1/24. Supervisor 1 told Staff 1 he didn’t have to complete 2
weeks, and he could be done working after their meeting, but he
wanted to continue working the 2 weeks. Supervisor 1 reported
this incident occurred during the 2-week timeframe. Supervisor 1
reported there was a team group post on 2/14/24 and a staff
meeting on 2/28/24 detailing the expectations for bed checks and
documentation because another staff was fired for not completing
bed checks as required.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
5/13/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 2
reported the expectation is for staff to put their eyes on youth, so
youth are to leave their bedroom doors cracked. Supervisor 2
reported she and Supervisor 1 randomly pull bed check logs and
review video footage to compare them to bed checks, and they
inform staff of this process as well.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage of the boy’s hallway, girl’s hallway, and recreation
room from 4/25/24-4/26/24 were reviewed on 6/10/24. It should be
noted there is no audio. The videos for the bedroom hallways
begin on 4/26/24 at 12:00 AM and end at 3:25 AM. The videos for
the recreation room begin on 4/26/24 at 12:00 AM and end at 1:16
AM.
• Staff 1 had air pods in his ears and was seated at the table
in the recreation room with his back facing the wall adjacent
to the bedroom hallways. Staff 1 didn’t acknowledge when
Youth C entered the recreation room until Youth C stood
and waved her hands in front of Staff 1.
• During the 3-3.5 hours of videos reviewed, Staff 1 had
eyes-on contact eight times for Youth A, four times for
Youth B, five times for Youth C and one time for Youth D.
• Youth D was in Youth B’s bedroom from 12:47-2:45 AM
and Youth C was in Youth A’s bedroom from 1:27-2:52 AM.
5

o During those timeframes, Staff 1 conducted one bed
check in each of the four youths’ rooms (2:19-2:20
AM).
TOUR OBSERVATION:
A tour of the facility occurred on 5/13/24. Observed the layout and
orientation of the two hallways (girl’s hallway & boy’s hallway),
door connecting the two hallways, youth rooms, kitchen, and
recreation room. The recreation room has access to each of the
bedroom hallways as well as the kitchen. If sitting with back facing
the wall adjacent to the bedroom hallways, you can’t see the
hallways to see if people are moving.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Staff Schedule from 4/21/24-4/27/24 notes Staff 1 was the
only staff assigned to work third shift from 4/25/24-4/26/24.
• Bed check logs for Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth
D documented consistent bed checks were completed
every 15 minutes or less, which did not coincide with videos
reviewed.
• Progress Note dated 5/8/24 as well as Incident and Risk
Management Report Form dated 5/9/24, both authored by
Staff 2 note Youth D told him she and Youth C conspired
and succeeded to sneak into Youth A and Youth B’s rooms
one night. Youth D told Staff 2 she had sex with Youth B,
but she didn’t think Youth A and Youth C “did anything”.
Staff 2 notified Supervisor 2. Cameras were reviewed and
confirmed the 4/26/24 incident.
o Supervisor 2 completed a post-incident analysis for
future prevention/risk management and noted to
prevent similar situations in the future, staff are
expected not to wear ear plugs, perform bed checks
as required, and be alert during shift.
• Bed Check Policy states any staff on duty should not create
an environment that could induce sleep or create the
appearance of being asleep. Bedroom checks shall not
exceed 15 minutes and must be at variable intervals
(examples provided). Any time a youth is in their room for
at least 5 minutes, a room check must occur and be
documented on the log, following the interval requirements.
Staff can use flashlights to do room checks. When staff
perform a bedroom check, they must answer the following
four questions:
6

o Are all youth in their assigned beds (identify by face,
body size, clothing worn at bedtime, etc.)?
o Are youth alive, appear well, and asleep?
o Is the room occupied by only those who should be
there?
o Is the room secure?
• Staff 1 does not have any formal disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 1’s 90-day evaluation dated 4/2/24
(signed 4/17/24), identified Staff 1 needed improvement in
the areas of attendance, communication, follow-through,
initiative, crisis management, and documentation. It noted
[Staff 1] gave his 2-weeks’ notice at the time of the
evaluation (4/17/24). It also noted [Staff 1] was having
issues staying awake on shift, being on time for shift, and
communicating with staff, which was discussed with him on
1/29/24. Staff 1 received training on program specific
procedures, including supervision requirements, during
orientation on 1/11/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per videos reviewed,
Staff 1 did not complete bed checks as required.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered as follows:
- The facility should not allow staff to work alone if there are
concerns with a staff’s performance leading to potential
safety issues.
- Facility’s bed check policy should be updated to reflect
eyes-on checks must require a staff to see a part of a
youth’s body to identify a youth is in their bed and should
not include “body size and clothing worn at bedtime”.
Consultation:
Consultation was offered to the facility regarding the following:
- If staff sit with their back facing the mural wall adjacent to
the bedroom hallways, there is limited to no visibility into
the hallways.
- Keeping the kitchen door leading to the bedroom hallway
closed with a chime or bell on it may deter youth from
entering the opposite gender’s hallway from the kitchen,
which is out of staff’s sight if staff are in the recreation
room.
- Staff’s use of noise cancelling headphones, air pods, etc.
while they’re on shift may prevent them from being able to
hear or be alerted to youth activity, safety concerns, etc.
7

- Since the beds are high enough for youth to fit underneath,
the facility should consider updating the bed check policy to
include checking under beds to ensure the room is
occupied by only those youth who should be there if youth
aren’t accounted for elsewhere.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & ACT 116 - 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination
Section of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
Description department, bureau of fire services, or local authorities;
records; reports report; forms; confidentiality; disclosure of
information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of
licensee to cooperation with investigation, inspection or
examination.
1. The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate
and examine the books and records of the licensee. The
licensee shall cooperate with the department’s
investigation, inspection, and examination by doing all of
the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and
household members, to provide accurate and truthful
information to the department.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 1 documented times for bed checks he did not complete.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/22/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor 1 reported she
never had a reason to believe Staff 1 was falsifying bed check
documentation previously. Supervisor 1 reported when she
completed random video reviews and compared those reviews to
documentation received, the bed check logs were accurate.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/22/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he is not sure if he ever
wrote down bed checks he didn’t complete in the past. However,
he stated since the video footage reviewed only showed he
completed one check on 4/26/24, obviously he wrote down checks
he didn’t complete.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage of the boy’s hallway, girl’s hallway, and recreation
room from 4/26/24-4/27/24 were reviewed on 6/10/24. The videos
8

begin on 4/27/24 at 12:00 AM and end at 3:25 AM. Staff 1 is not
seen completing any paperwork during the timeframe listed
above. Staff 1 conducted one bed check in each of the four
youths’ rooms between 2:19-2:20 AM. During the 3-3.5 hours of
videos reviewed, Staff 1 had eyes-on contact eight times for Youth
A, four times for Youth B, five times for Youth C and one time for
Youth D.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Room Check/Supervision Logs for Youth A, Youth B, Youth
C and Youth D dated 4/26/24 were reviewed. Staff 1
documented he completed checks every 15 minutes or less
for each youth. In documenting each check, Staff 1 also
listed whether each youth was awake or asleep on their
individual logs. Many of these statuses were documented
during times video shows Staff 1 did not complete eyes-on
checks on the youth.
• Bedroom Checks Policy states when a bedroom check has
been completed, staff must document the time the check
was completed on each youth’s individual log.
• Staff 1 does not have any formal disciplinary records in his
employee file. Staff 1’s 90-day evaluation dated 4/2/24
(signed 4/17/24), identified Staff 1 needed improvement in
the areas of attendance, communication, follow-through,
initiative, crisis management, and documentation. It noted
[Staff 1] gave his 2-weeks’ notice at the time of the
evaluation (4/17/24). It also noted [Staff 1] was having
issues staying awake on shift, being on time for shift, and
communicating with staff, which was discussed with him on
1/29/24. Staff 1 received training on program specific
procedures, including supervision requirements, during
orientation on 1/11/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as Staff 1 documented he
completed bed checks he did not complete per videos reviewed.
Conclusion Violation Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
